nodes.text: R: FAS FAS : Steven L. Davis pled guilty yesterday to federal charges that he stole and disclosed trade secrets of The Gillette Company
Federation Of American Scientists : Steven L. Davis pled guilty yesterday to federal charges that he stole and disclosed trade secrets of The Gillette Company
Asserting
Steven L. Davis pled guilty on January 27th 1998 to federal charges that he stole and disclosed trade secrets of The Gillette Company
R: Federation Of American Scientists : Steven L. Davis pled guilty yesterday to federal charges that he stole and disclosed trade secrets of The Gillette Company

Federation Of American Scientists : United States Attorney Donald K. Stern and Barry Mawn, Special Agent in Charge of the Boston office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced today that STEVEN L. DAVIS, 47, currently residing in Kansas City, Missouri, pled guilty before U.S. District Judge Thomas Higgins in Nashville, Tennessee, to 5 counts of theft of trade secrets
Asserting

United States Attorney Donald K. Stern and Barry Mawn, Special Agent in Charge of the Boston office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced today that STEVEN L. DAVIS, 47, currently residing in Kansas City, Missouri, pled guilty before U.S. District Judge Thomas Higgins in Nashville, Tennessee, to 5 counts of theft of trade secrets

R: Federation Of American Scientists : United States Attorney Donald K. Stern and Barry Mawn, Special Agent in Charge of the Boston office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced today that STEVEN L. DAVIS, 47, currently residing in Kansas City, Missouri, pled guilty before U.S. District Judge Thomas Higgins in Nashville, Tennessee, to 5 counts of theft of trade secrets
Default Transition
Default Rephrase
Restating

Federation Of American Scientists : At the change of plea hearing, a federal prosecutor told the court that in February and March, 1997, DAVIS stole and disclosed trade secrets concerning the development of a new shaving system by The Gillette Company, which is headquartered in Boston, Massachusetts
Asserting

At the change of plea hearing, a federal prosecutor told the court that in February and March, 1997, DAVIS stole and disclosed trade secrets concerning the development of a new shaving system by The Gillette Company, which is headquartered in Boston, Massachusetts

R: Federation Of American Scientists : At the change of plea hearing, a federal prosecutor told the court that in February and March, 1997, DAVIS stole and disclosed trade secrets concerning the development of a new shaving system by The Gillette Company, which is headquartered in Boston, Massachusetts
Default Transition
Default Inference
Arguing

Federation Of American Scientists : DAVIS, was employed as a process controls engineer for Wright Industries, Inc., a Tennessee designer of fabrication equipment, which had been hired by Gillette to assist in the development of the new shaving system
Asserting

DAVIS, was employed as a process controls engineer for Wright Industries, Inc., a Tennessee designer of fabrication equipment, which had been hired by Gillette to assist in the development of the new shaving system

R: Federation Of American Scientists : DAVIS, was employed as a process controls engineer for Wright Industries, Inc., a Tennessee designer of fabrication equipment, which had been hired by Gillette to assist in the development of the new shaving system
Default Transition
Default Inference
Arguing
Federation Of American Scientists : The new shaving system project was extremely confidential and was treated so by both Gillette and Wright Industries
Asserting
The new shaving system project was extremely confidential and was treated so by both Gillette and Wright Industries
R: Federation Of American Scientists : The new shaving system project was extremely confidential and was treated so by both Gillette and Wright Industries
Federation Of American Scientists : DAVIS told the court that in anger at a supervisor
Asserting
DAVIS told the court that in anger at a supervisor
R: Federation Of American Scientists : DAVIS told the court that in anger at a supervisor
Federation Of American Scientists : fearing that his job was in jeopardy
Asserting
DAVIS feared that his job was in jeopardy
R: Federation Of American Scientists : fearing that his job was in jeopardy
Federation Of American Scientists : he decided to disclose trade secret information to Gillette's competitors
Asserting
DAVIS decided to disclose trade secret information to Gillette's competitors
R: Federation Of American Scientists : he decided to disclose trade secret information to Gillette's competitors

Federation Of American Scientists : The disclosures were made to Warner-Lambert Co., Bic, and American Safety Razor Co. DAVIS has agreed in a plea agreement that the loss caused by his conduct is at least $1.5 million
Asserting
The disclosures were made to Warner-Lambert Co., Bic, and American Safety Razor Co. DAVIS has agreed in a plea agreement that the loss caused by his conduct is at least $1.5 million

R: Federation Of American Scientists : The disclosures were made to Warner-Lambert Co., Bic, and American Safety Razor Co. DAVIS has agreed in a plea agreement that the loss caused by his conduct is at least $1.5 million

Default Inference
Arguing

Arguing

Default Inference
Arguing
Default Transition
Default Inference
Arguing

Federation Of American Scientists : In October 1996, concerned about both domestic and foreign economic espionage, Congress criminalized the disclosure of trade secrets relating to products sold in interstate commerce. This case is the first case involving a Massachusetts victim
Asserting

In October 1996, concerned about both domestic and foreign economic espionage, Congress criminalized the disclosure of trade secrets relating to products sold in interstate commerce. This case is the first case involving a Massachusetts victim

R: Federation Of American Scientists : In October 1996, concerned about both domestic and foreign economic espionage, Congress criminalized the disclosure of trade secrets relating to products sold in interstate commerce. This case is the first case involving a Massachusetts victim

Federation Of American Scientists : Judge Higgins scheduled sentencing for April 17, 1998. At that time, DAVIS faces a 10-year term of imprisonment on each of the 5 trade secrets counts, and a fine of $250,000 on each count. He may also be required to pay restitution to the victims
Asserting

Judge Higgins scheduled sentencing for April 17, 1998. At that time, DAVIS faces a 10-year term of imprisonment on each of the 5 trade secrets counts, and a fine of $250,000 on each count. He may also be required to pay restitution to the victims

R: Federation Of American Scientists : Judge Higgins scheduled sentencing for April 17, 1998. At that time, DAVIS faces a 10-year term of imprisonment on each of the 5 trade secrets counts, and a fine of $250,000 on each count. He may also be required to pay restitution to the victims

Federation Of American Scientists : This case was investigated by the Boston Office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation with assistance from the FBI's Nashville Office. The case is being prosecuted in Tennessee by Assistant U.S. Attorney Jeanne M. Kempthorne, Deputy Chief of Stern's Economic Crimes Unit, with the assistance of Assistant U.S. Attorney Wendy Goggin, of the U.S. Attorney's Office in Nashville
Asserting

This case was investigated by the Boston Office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation with assistance from the FBI's Nashville Office. The case is being prosecuted in Tennessee by Assistant U.S. Attorney Jeanne M.
